 Summary: 
 
 The Refugee Board dismissed Miranda's claim that he was a refugee. Miranda applied for judicial review. 
 
 
 
 The Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, dismissed the application.

 Admission - Refugees - Refugee division - Determination by - [See

 ]. 
 
 
 
 Aliens - Topic 1331 
 
 Admission - Refugees - Evidence - The Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, stated that "[f]or the purposes of judicial review ... a Refugee Board's decision must be interpreted as a whole. One might approach it with a pathologist's scalpel, subject it to a microscopic examination or perform a kind of semantic autopsy on particular statements found in the decision. But mostly ... the decision must be analyzed in the context of the evidence itself. ... it is an effective way to decide if the conclusions reached were reasonable or patently unreasonable" - See paragraph 3 - "Although one may isolate one comment from the Board's decision and find some error therein, the error must nevertheless be material to the decision reached" - See paragraph 4. 
 
 
 
 Aliens - Topic 1334 
 
 Admission - Refugees - Appeals - Scope of review - [See  
 Aliens - Topic 1331 
 ]. 
 
 
 
 Counsel: 
 
 Jack C. Martin, for the applicant; 
 
 Cheryl D. Mitchell, for the respondent. 
 
 
 
 Solicitors of Record: 
 
 Jack C. Martin, Toronto, Ontario, for the applicant; 
 
 John C. Tait, Q.C., Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, for the respondent. 
 
 
 
 This application was heard on April 28, 1993, at Toronto, Ontario, before Joyal, J., of the Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, who delivered judgment orally on April 28, 1993, followed by written reasons on May 6, 1993. 
 
 
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[1] 
   
 Joyal, J. 
 : The following is further to the order and brief oral reasons therefore which I issued at the close of the hearing on this application for judicial review.

[2] 
  There is no doubt that counsel for the applicant has articulately set out the parameters to which the Refugee Board must adhere when dealing with a refugee claim. I am in full agreement with him that a departure from these parameters, as well as certain doctrines propounded from time to time by the Federal Court of Appeal, do provide adequate safeguards to an unsuccessful refugee claimant who comes before this court for review. Otherwise, the impugned decision will be quashed. There has been, as we all know, a plethora of Appeal decisions quashing credibility panel or Refugee Board decisions.

[3] 
  For purposes of judicial review, however, it is my view that a Refugee Board's decision must be interpreted as a whole. One might approach it with a pathologist's scalpel, subject it to a microscopic examination or perform a kind of semantic autopsy on particular statements found in the decision. But mostly, in my view, the decision must be analyzed in the context of the evidence itself. I believe it is an effective way to decide if the conclusions reached were reasonable or patently unreasonable.

[4] 
  I have now read through the transcript of the evidence before the Board and I have listened to arguments from both counsel. Although one may isolate one comment from the Board's decision and find some error therein, the error must nevertheless be material to the decision reached. And this is where I fail to find any kind of error.

[5] 
  It is true that artful pleaders can find any number of errors when dealing with decisions of administrative tribunals. Yet we must always remind ourselves of what the Supreme Court of Canada said on a criminal appeal where the grounds of appeal were some 12 errors in the judge's charge to the jury. In rendering judgment, the court stated that it had found 18 errors in the judge's charge, but that in the absence of any miscarriage of justice, the appeal could not succeed.

[6] 
  This is the point I am trying to establish here. One may look at the decision of the Board, then one may balance it off against the evidence found in the transcript and the evidence of the claimant himself in trying to justify his objective as well as subjective fears of persecution.

[7] 
  On the basis of that analysis, I find that the conclusions reached by the Refugee Board are well-founded on the evidence. There can always be conflict on the evidence. There is always the possibility of an opposite decision from a differently constituted Board. Anyone might have reached a different conclusion. Different conclusions may often be reached if one perhaps subscribes to different value systems. But in spite of counsel for the applicant's thorough exposition, I have failed to grasp forcefully the kind of error in the Board's decision which would justify my intervention. The Board's decision, in my view, is fully consistent with the evidence.

[8] 
  The Trial Division of this court is just now entering into this field of judicial review, and I believe that it will try to subscribe to and respect the guidelines which have been expressed by the Court of Appeal. This is easily said but not always easily applied when dealing with particular cases. I should hope that counsel will share that concern as the Trial Division assumes this new jurisdiction. 
 
 
 
 Application dismissed. 
 
 
 
 Editor: Gary W. McLaughlin/blk 
 
 
 
 [End of document]

legal_issues: The appropriate standard and scope of review applicable to decisions made by administrative tribunals.
Whether an error identified in an administrative decision is material to the overall outcome.
The extent to which a reviewing court should consider individual elements of a decision versus the decision as a whole, in the context of the evidence presented.
The circumstances under which a reviewing court will intervene in a decision made by an administrative tribunal, even if alternative conclusions were possible.
The role of credibility assessments in administrative decision-making and their review by the courts.
factual_background: An individual, Miranda, made a claim for refugee status.
The Refugee Board reviewed and dismissed Miranda's claim.
Miranda sought judicial review of the Refugee Board's decision.
The Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, reviewed Miranda's application for judicial review.
The Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, also dismissed the application.
The review involved consideration of a transcript of evidence presented to the Refugee Board and the claimant's stated fears of persecution.

Applicants: The Refugee Board failed to adhere to the correct parameters when assessing the refugee claim.
The Board's decision was inconsistent with the evidence presented.
The claimant had objective and subjective fears of persecution.
Respondents: The Refugee Board's decision must be interpreted as a whole, in the context of the evidence.
Any errors in the Board's decision were not material to the ultimate decision.
The Board's conclusions were well-founded on the evidence.
The Trial Division should respect the guidelines established by the Court of Appeal in refugee law.

court_analysis: The court emphasized that judicial review of Refugee Board decisions requires analyzing the decision as a whole, in the context of the entire evidence presented, rather than focusing on isolated errors.

The court acknowledged the existence of established safeguards for refugee claimants and the potential for quashing decisions with procedural errors, but stated that not every error warrants intervention.
The court applied a 'materiality' standard, holding that even if an error is identified in the Board's reasoning, it must be material to the ultimate decision to justify judicial intervention.

Drawing an analogy to a criminal appeal, the court reasoned that the presence of errors does not automatically necessitate overturning a decision if no miscarriage of justice occurred – meaning the decision remains reasonably supported by the evidence.

The court found the Refugee Board’s conclusions to be well-founded on the evidence presented, acknowledging that differing interpretations or value systems could lead to different conclusions, but that this did not constitute a reviewable error.

The court expressed a desire for the Trial Division to respect the guidelines established by the Court of Appeal in conducting judicial reviews of Refugee Board decisions, recognizing the challenges of applying these guidelines in specific cases.
